children.subject: How about if I switch 188 and 186 in combo 1? So I take 61c + 186 in the fall and 161 + 188 in the spring.

61c + 186: These are both project heavy classes. CS186 has around 6 projects (some are really long) and the class has gotten difficult over the years according to older students. I took it last semester and the projects were just too long imo. 61c is a lot of work as well. If these are the only two techs you'll be taking, then it might be more than doable depending on your abilities. 

161 + 188: I've taken 161 and it's a fantastic class with a low-medium workload. I haven't taken 188 but I heard that it's one of the easier upper-divs. This will be a chill semester. 

Overall: I'd still go with combo 1.

Combo 1 is the most reasonable. It'll give you time to digest the material as well as take part in extracurricular activities if you're into that. You want to avoid combos 2 and 3. Ideally, if you're taking cs61c, you want to only take one more tech. The same applies to cs162. (I wish I followed this advice myself).

history.content:
Afaik, 186, 61c, 161 and 162 are project heavy classes. So, people recommend not taking two of them together. However, I've really got to finish off these 4 classes in the next 3 semesters. How should I spread them out?

I can't take 161 and 162 before 61c, so I'm taking 61c first for sure. I am also almost definitely taking 188 next sem. I was considering the following combos:

Combo 1:

Fall 2021: 61C + 188

Spring 2022: 161 + 186

Fall 2022: 162 + another tech

Combo 2:

Fall 2021: 61C + 186 + 188

Spring 2022: 161 + 162

Combo 3:

Fall 2021: 61C + 186 + 188

Spring 2022: 161 + another tech

Fall 2022: 162 + another tech

The other techs I wanna take are EE126/Stat140, EE127 (maybe) and CS 189, which I will adjust according to however I plan out 161, 162 and 186.
history.subject: How to spread out 61c, 186, 161, 162 over 3 semesters?
